description.text:
It sounds like Jurassic Park 4 is returning to Isla Nublar.  The most obvious plot (to me) is that a big game hunter will be organizing 'unique' hunting expedition which of course go horribly, horribly, horribly wrong.  He'll need something to attract lovable, yet hopelessly naive billionaires, so on his office wall is a Hunting trophy!   
Jeff Goldblum will invite himself along and later, shaking his head and looking at the first body will say something like 'Oh look, another demonstration of survival of the fittest'.  That's the film I want! :)

I took Otaku's excellent model, chopped off part of the shoulders (to fit on the plaque) and put a simple plaque behind it.  I printed it at high res on a Makerbot2 with rafting and support without issue.  (6cm tall, with plaque flat on plate)  This is Otaku's low res version.  If there's interest, I'll wrangle up a machine with a bit more horse power and crank out a hi-res version.  
This was meant as a quick and dirty joke for a friend: If you have any problems with it, let me know!

description.text: We needed a clock in the RepRap Lab at Bath University. So, of course, we made one. It's shown mounted on the MDF build platform from ARNIE - the very first prototype RepRap that we made. See RepRap history at: http://blog.reprap.org/2007/02/arnie-gives-it-shot.html Naturally the hours are in binary...

This uses the standard one-AA-battery quartz clock movement that seems to drive just about every analogue clock in the world. It's the black rectangle in the picture below with the brass nut next to it. In the UK you can get these for a couple of quid from Maplin: http://www.maplin.co.uk/module.aspx?TabID=1&criteria=usb&ModuleNo=5034&C=SO&U=Strat15 Start by printing all the parts. You'll need 12 of the hour segments; one each of the rest. Place the hour segments in a circle on a plastic bag on a flat surface. Put a weight in the middle, and string a large elastic band round the segments to hold them together. As an alternative to an elastic band, I used cable-ties chained together. The weight is to stop the middle flipping up, which it will do if you put the tension on without the weight. Dribble super-glue down the cracks between the segments and allow it to set. The plastic bag was to stop the clock sticking to the flat surface on which you're doing the gluing. Also glue the hour hand into its centre. Spray paint the hands a contrasting colour to the rest of the clock. Print out the file pips.pdf and cut the pips out carefully with scissors. Put the pips in the recesses in the clock perimeter. I found that I could push them in with a small screwdriver and they would stay without glue, but you may need to put a small dab of glue on the back of each one. Now. You can count in binary, can't you? Attach the movement to the clock face. You may need to put a fat washer under the nut - they seem to come with different retaining-ring diameters. Put the hands on. You may need to clean out the holes with a drill bit. Start undersized and work up - you don't want the holes to get too big as you want a snug fit. Put in a battery, set the time, and hang the clock on a nail in the wall. Hey Presto! It's time to go down the pub.

This is a remix of the model "To revive a unicorn" made by a girl called Mathilde at a workshop at a afterschool programme for kids as part of the project "To revive a unicorn". The project explores 3D-printings ability to make art accessible to everyone, everywhere and become an everyday-experience,
as well as its capability to let people rework and remix art and find new purposes and contexts for art pieces. As part of the project I want to encourage you and everyone else to use this model in whatever way you can imagine - Remix it, hack it or just print it and use it as it is, for what you want. And I will highly appreciate you sharing photos, models and other documentation of what you might do whith it, both here and and on Instagram with the hastag #toreviveaunicorn. Thanks :)

Modeled for the UMass Library Digital Media Lab. This armature was modeled after an existing one that came off of a Pearstone VT-2100 Tripod.  
This is the second model and has been tested. To attach, extend the legs of the tripod and line up the holes with to their corresponding partners on the tripod. Insert the pins. Despite having much larger holes that the diameter of the pins, the existing ones on the tripod itself will hold them in place.  
Recommended 80% infill.

However its a pretty cool shape and even a lampshade or whatever. So I thought i'd upload it for others to enjoy. I've split into two sections which still need to be scaled to .8 to fit on my 20x20x20 printer. Each half takes around 6 hours to print to.
Print both sections, then i glued them together followed by welding with a flat head soldering iron. Finishing is whatever you chose.

author: holyco

description.text: Also known as Clock-in-a-Cage! WARNING! Since we still don't have a working escapement mechanism (see test jig #2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8275 ), this is NOT a working clock, yet. Hopefully, it will be eventually. :-) The Planetary Gearbox Clock is a collaboration with Emmett, who designed the original planetary gearbox and helped design and stack two of them with a 60:1 and 12:1 ratio respectively. I just slapped the escapement system on the back side and designed a cage-frame around it. The dove-tail snap-fit tabs for the cage I took from relet's excellent http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6214 . The intent was to do away with concentric shafts altogether, by putting the entire gear-train inside the shaft, as it were. The frame must hold the stator rings without interfering with the hands that stick out the side of the rotor rings, hence the cage design.

This is officially part of the Printable Clock Project and is being maintained on GitHub along with the rest of the code:
https://github.com/syvwlch/Printable-Clock-Project The script posted here was used to generate the images, but the latest version will be on GitHub. Feel free to fork it and play with it, any improvements and/or variants welcome! I will post STLs when it is ready for testing (not until we have a working escapement), and remove the WIP flag when someone has a print of it ticking properly.

comments.text: The side cross-bracing that links the 4 main struts, they look like the webbing on a truss (or bridge). They hold the struts in position. On that Thing they are listed as Web.S1 etc. Basically a vertical dovetail in the side of the 'bone' pieces that connect the outer walls of the clock to the gears, so you can have vertical parts that hold them positioned correctly. You might have trouble fitting them in without getting in the way of the Hands, but they would be the best way of getting those links to stay exactly where they should.

comments.text: The total print uses around 20M of filament and takes 16-18 hours depending on what printer and settings you use. You can make about 4 per roll. If you are selling to a friend I suggest just charging for the material cost, as 3D printing takes a long time and is not cost effective if you count value for production time. I would sell one for around $20 AUD to make a profit of $15 each. Also if you want to sell them, ask the original creator as well for permission.

title: Dualstrusion Ring Gear for Automatic Transmission

description.text: I found the 'Output' text difficult to read on the original, and messed up a couple prints by not pausing at exactly the right time to make the indicator a different color. So, I changed it to have the outer shell and indicator a second color.

I used MakerWare's medium. I recommend 2 shells, 0.27mm layer height, and pretty fast (I did 90 mm/s). This helps with many issues from switching printing heads. Slower speeds can leave one head with PLA sitting in it for long periods, causing flow issues and clogs. Lower flow from smaller layer height does the same thing. I occasionally had problems with a single shell due to a couple messed up gear teeth since there is only one chance to get the outline correct and there were sometimes flow issues switching colors. This is no problem if it goes over it one more time with a second shell.

I've tested printing the arm in both PLA and nylon. The PLA arm works great and has no performance impact on the quad. I haven't crashed with it yet, so I can't speak for how tough it is, but it feels fairly rigid at 20% infill and 3 shells.
The nylon arm is way too flexible to be used, but I want to experiment some more because I believe that a nylon arm would be fairly indestructible.

title: Magazine and magazine attachment for E11 stormtrooper blaster

description.text: This is a remix of the magazine and attachment from ProCoPrint3D's E11, simplified for easy printing and scaled for a 40 mm pipe build.

The original has been simplified and sliced for easy printing. The full parts checked out OK in NetFabb, and should print OK, if your printer is up for it. Mine isn't. The attachment has been printed and tested and seemed to be a fairly good fit on a 40 mm pipe.The walls of the attachment part that goes on the pipe have been thickened slightly to avoid breakage when used. The inner part of the magazine has been slimmed down a bit to fit in the attachment with thicker walls, but is slightly wide and will need some work for a snug fit. I thought it prudent to make it slightly big and grind it down instead of risking a magazine that keeps falling out. The magazine itself has been test printed too, but I've not had time to grind it down to fit the attachment. It seems to be close enough to work with. It's not hollow, by the way, although I may make a hollow version later on. It'd be a nice place to keep a power source for any electronics. The STL of the full attachment does not have thickened walls, and may be a bit flimsy if you should choose to print it.

author: Yngel

description.text: Well, it could be a four way flow control valve if you don't need an "off" position. Or if you can find a servo with 300 degree action it can have six positions. The photo is shown with only one tube, but you will need a tube for each input you want to control. The inner disk rotates, pinching all but one input at a time. This thing was inspired in part by this guy's video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0h9cLpLw_9E&feature=player_embedded. UPDATE: Video of this thing in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eBHl2WdncW0

This thing was designed to use this servo http://www.phidgets.com/products.php?product_id=3000 and this servo controller http://www.phidgets.com/products.php?category=11&product_id=1061, which can control up to 8 servos. They also sell a single servo controller, but you will have to modify the pcb holder part and the code to control it will differ slightly. The java file is a code snippet that shows how to turn a single input on for 10 seconds. The pichwheel.stl file is just for the pretty render here on thingiverse, and is not useful for printing. You will also need some 5mm (outer diameter) rubber tubing. The squishier the better. Print 3 axels, 2 pcb holders and up to six sliders. Print one of everything else. Assemble. Plug into USB port. Control the flow.

comments.text: Can you bypass without releasing?  I would like to use this to control the output of a multi-channel perastaltic pump (one motor, five hoses)
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: You could minimize the bypass release by turning off the peristaltic pump while switching outputs. I'm using it with a gravity fed system, but even so the amount of bypass release is minor enough that it works for my purposes. Plus it's consistent enough that I'm  able to compensate for it in the software.

remixed_from.title: Geeetech I3 pro 8mm Acrylic Filament Holder and Mount

title: Geeetech i3 Pro 8mm Acrylic filament holder & mount remix

description.text:
The filament holder designed by msmith358 is great, but needed improving.  The side panels had some polygon issues, and weren't printable on all platforms, so I fixed that.  Also, there was only room for short screws.  To improve flexibility, I redesigned it to allow longer screws as well.  I only happened to have regular drywall screws lying around, and they work great on this new remix, as should a lot of others now.  Flexibility is a good thing.  
Also, I think the new curvyness really looks good.  
EDIT:  I have also posted the base on each side with tweaks.  Skip to instructions for details.

Side Panel Changes
  • Fixed triangle overlap errors in model that made it un-sliceable in slic3r.
  • Much deeper screw holes, so more options in screw types possible, depending on what the builder has lying around. I used standard 1-5/8" drywall screws that I scrounged from my messy shop area.
  • New curvy shape to accommodate the deeper screw holes. Real men love curves.
    • Base Plate Changes
  • Increased depth for rod sockets for better fit.
  • Slightly shifted "L" profile bracket shape for better fit of acrylic panel.
  • Shortened positioning nubs to correctly align with vertical acrylic panel edges.
    NOTE: Support structure is recommended for the "L" profiled bracket area. It's not much but it makes a big difference.

comments.text: Hi, I used blender to convert the STL's into something AutoCAD likes, and then loaded it up in AutoCAD Architecture 2012.  It has a decent toolkit of volume editing tools for conceptual design, plus the dead-on precision and stability that AutoCAD is famous for.  By extremely old version of AutoCAD, out of curiosity, what do you mean?  I remember doing 3D modelling using AutoCAD for DOS.  :)

title: 1.9 and 1.55 RC Scale Truck Wheel with Hubcaps

description.text:
what you get is a super fine crafted wheel with simulated lugnuts and a set of hubcaps for the Front- and Rearaxle, a beadlock ring and a ring for the inside of the tire. The Beadlock Ring can be screwed to the wheel with 3x12mm screws with plastic thread. Printing: I recommend PLA for printing. The screws will hold very good in this material. You can use the standard settings for PLA. 12.04.2016: Low poly hubcaps added. 12.01.2016: I did some updates for user 802. The database now contains a second rim assembly for 31mm narrow tires. Please use the files "felgenhorn_narrow_21mm.stl",
"Felge_narrow_21mm.stl" and "ring_narrow.stl". With the part "spacer_between_wheelhalfes.stl" you can adjust the width of the rim and the part "spacer_12mm_hex.stl" is for adjusting the backspacing of the rim. Both spacer have a thickness of 1mm. If you use the spacer_between_wheelhalfes.stl, you have to offset the part ring_narrow.stl the same amount of spacers used. If you can´t do that, please email me, I can can do it for you!!! 13.01.2016: Updated part "Felge_narrow_21mm.stl": The material between the 12mm hex and outer rim surface was too thin (only 1mm, think it will break under heavy stress) on former design. Now it has 3mm wall thickness, but the 12mm hex of your axle will only go 3mm into the rim. 08.02.2016: here is another update done for user gutek110. I`ve scaled the wheel down to use it with 1.55 tires. I don´t have a 1.55 Tire, so I can´t test this rim if it works correctly with the 1.55 tires. 05.01.17: I´ve changed the fileformat of the original 1.9 rim to STL-binary. Some people have problems with the STL-ascii format. So if you want to print the rim with 1.9 inch in diameter and 25mm wide use the files ending with ...binary.stl. In this video you can see my Truck with this Wheels in Action.
It´s a slow motion video, so have a little time!!
https://youtu.be/daQMnrBYJ54 For a cool "A-Team" style rim, visit my homepage at:
https://www.printable-3d-models.com/en/scale-truck-rim-A-TEAM-1-9.html

title: The unicorn who lost its horn

description.text:
This is a remix of the model "To revive a unicorn" made by one of the girls at a workshop at a afterschool programme for kids as part of the project "To revive a unicorn". The project explores 3D-printings ability to make art accessible to everyone, everywhere and become an everyday-experience,
as well as its capability to let people rework and remix art and find new purposes and contexts for art pieces. As part of the project I want to encourage you and everyone else to use this model in whatever way you can imagine - Remix it, hack it or just print it and use it as it is, for what you want. And I will highly appreciate you sharing photos, models and other documentation of what you might do whith it, both here and and on Instagram with the hastag #toreviveaunicorn. Thanks :)

remixed_from.author: cray2mpx
remixed_from.title: Dew protection cap for Celestron Edge HD 8" telescope

description.text:
This is my version of a dew shield for a 9.25" Celestron Telescope  Fits both Edge and XLT versions.  Snaps in place of the lens cover and has hold for pins to install the lens cover at the end of the dew shield.  I have also included the SolidWorks files if you want to scale this down to a 8", 6" or smaller scope.  
This model needs at least a Z18, or Type 1A printer to fit... And it takes almost 2 pounds of plastic.   On my X18 it took almost 65 hrs to produce.

Printed on a modified Z18
Default "FAST" setting
Other than that, you'll need about 3 days to print and at least 2 pounds of PLA on the spool.

comments.text: Wow that's great. I've been looking for a file for my 11" edge SCT. The scope is in an observatory, I need a real short dew shield that the scope wouldn't hit the walls or the dome when slewing. It would also not fit my print bed of 10x10 so it would need to be printed in parts. I don't know how to design, would it be to hard to adapt your design into an 11" one?

comments.text: Hi, I am very new in the 3d printing community, so I apologize in advance if this is a stupid question. Is it possible the shorten the tube to the point that its the locking mechanism and say 80mm of tube so I can make the rest of the body from a material of my choice? So i guess what i am trying to say.. is it possible to edit the print file to just print the locking mech + 80mm?

Sure I will try to post something in a day or two.
I found that the tube of this size in PLA is not that stable and one hot day in the sun and it is not longer round... But some odd shape... sheet metal might be a better option for the rest of the tube

comments.text:
I really like your idea of using the dust cover mechanism to attach the dew shield, i made a dew sheild from an old foam camping mat but found it to be very clumsy and it interfered with my PWM dew heater , the foam acted like insulation stopping the straps from heating the corrector lens. Your design solves that problem!
Absolutely brilliant! Thank you again
comments.author: ur7x

title: Chassis mount for Steering Servo SCX10 Chassis

description.text:
If you want to relocate your steering servo of your Axial SCX10 chassis to the Frame, maybe you have found the right part. It works only on Trucks where the battery is mounted in the rear. Simply print the part, screw it to the existing mounting point, install your steering servo and arm (maybe some modifications to the lenght of the steering arm can be necessary), have Fun!!!! Use PLA or ABS for printing (standard settings)
PS: The wheels are also available on youmagine.com

comments.text: Just FYI you can have your battery mounted in the front for this to work. Just gotta be creative!

comments.text:
Hi, Laird
Thanks for you hard work, it's wonderful!
But I found a small issue in Plate of Clips of this 3 mm version, in which cross ties are too closed to each other, so overlapped with adjacent.
I found parameter that define the interval of them in your SCAD file, just now.
Line 190:
for (y = [0:gridSpacing.9:plateY]) {
And I changed it to:
for (y = [0:gridSpacing.95:plateY]) {
They are just touch each other. If you want more space, just choose a bigger number.
Hope it is useful to you and others.

author: Teachafish

description.text: This is a simple case for Ray-Ban Aviator sunglasses. The intent is for it to be very slim so it takes up hardly any more space than the glasses, yet sturdy enough to offer real protection. All the cases I see in the stores are either soft (so they protect against scratches but not smacks or crushes), or bulky (five times the size of the glasses). This is a first try; it doesn't have a lid (but the glasses fit so snugly it might not need them, yet slide free easily) or a clip (I plan to make variations with a shirt clip and a sun-visor clip).

I printed mine with a 3mm brim to help make sure it stuck.  Probably didn't need it since the bottom is solid, but it does print a while (four hours on my Solidoodle 3) so I just wanted to be sure.  
If you don't have your filament width set properly, this can end up being very brittle and breaking along the horizontal plane of the layers.

comments.text: This was my first ever design done in SketchUp.  So it's very simple but still functional.  I'd love to get any input on how I could have done it better.  (Or how I can add clips or a lid easily, though I have some ideas there.)

author: Sanx

description.text: I modeled it for Nikon D90, not sure about compatibility with other models.
Should be safe to print as is, no support or anything.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/64yxEkSgQ8x
Just a 3D model of "USB Connector" I use to modify other designs to fit it.
Probably not useful to print but nice to have if you want to tailor a design to fit it.

It is a rack that you can use to hold air tools.  It is sized to use industrial quick-connect fittings.  There is a step in the bore to accommodate  for the fittings change in diameter and I modeled it so there is +.02" clearance on diameter to compensate for the polygons the slicers create in holes.  My tools fit with only a few thousandths of clearance on the printed part; perfect.  Mounts to a wall stud with clearance for two #10 wood screws.  It should be able to hold anything from a blow gun to an impact. It is 6" wide with holes for 4 tools.

Printed with 25% infill and it feels very stout.  I don't know if it will handle 4-impact guns (if you can fit them on here) but it is strong enough for a tire gauge and the couple of different blow guns that I will be using it for.

author: HorsePaintiVvianCoraci536

title: 2-in-1 fan duct: extruder and filament cooler for E3D V6 and others

description.text:
UPDATE 21-05-2015: Updated photo renders, STL fixed, updated source file.  
Because I did not want to place two fans around my hotend, one for the extruder cooling and one for the filament cooling, I decided to design a double fan duct which can cool both with only one 40mm fan. Results are pretty good, all prints come out great and I have not had any filament jamming so far.  
I have uploaded, next to the source files (Solidworks), two STL versions. One is designed to fit on the official E3D V6 hotend, one is designed for my Chinese E3D clone. They are both the same, except for the with and height of the fan mount. The official E3D has a diameter of 22.3mm and a height of 26mm, my clone has a diameter of 25mm and a height of 32mm. To check which version you need, just measure the diameter of your hotend. The length is less important as the diameter.  
Mounting is easy, just screw a 40mm fan with 4 M3 screws to the fan duct, click the fan duct to your hotend and you are good to go! The click-on system is really simple, but still very strong. Even with strong vibrations the fan duct on my printer does not move on the hotend.  
Printing can best be done by rotating the print 45 degrees and printing the fan duct with the fan mount to the bottom.  
The designs are with a GPL license. So do what you want with the files, as long as you publish your modificated object under a GPL license and give the correct references.

comments.text:
Hi there,
I like the shape, it's simple and elegant.
On the other hand, I don't think it's a good idea to join the two fans. The fan for the extruder has to run all the time, otherwise the heat flowing up from the hot end will overheat the extruder, the filament becomes too soft to go through the feeding line and the printer jams.
On my printer - and probably on others, too - it cannot be controlled, gets continuous power while the printer is switched on.
The other fan, which cools the extruded filament and the printed object - is another story. It can be controlled depending on filament materials, object shape, printing speed, etc. Most slicers control it layer by layer, or even more frequently (e.g. slic3r)
It will not necessarily cause problems to you until you print fairly simple shapes. The general risk is that in certain cases your 1st layer will not stick (enough) to the bed. Most slicers switch off the object fan for the 1st couple of layers, allowing them to melt better to the bed.

comments.text: I print PLA on bare heated glass (no hairspray or blue tape). I took some time to play with the settings just this afternoon and discovered the following solution. Turn the fan on to 50% via software, then heat up the extruder to 220c. Touch the heatsink to see if the temperature is ambient. if so, drop fan down to 40% and do the process over again to see how low you can drop you fan speed without compromising the passive cooling. My fan was able to do 20%~25% speed without raising the temperature of heatsink.
comments.author: Lurifaxen

comments.text: One additional problem i'm trying to workout is that my fan is wired to the D9 print fan, not the extruder fan. Print fan has the advantage of controlling fan speed via software at any given time (even with start script gcode), but start script gcode comes after heating up and before print. So without software, I don't know how i can turn the fan on before heating up without the printer connected to a desktop/laptop via software. say I want to print solely via SD Card. Dont know how to beat this part yet.

For me, I have set in Cura the option to have the fan off during the first layer and on 50% for every layer higher than 0.5mm. This works perfect for most of my prints. If I have to print a very big object, with a large sized first layer, the heatsink will heat up too much and can cause filament jamming. But large object do not need object cooling, only cooling for the heatsink, so for those prints I use a different fanduct which only cools the heatsink and not the object. For smaller objects, not cooling the heatsink for just a few minutes should not cause problems.

comments.text:
Thanks!
With which nozzle size do you print? Walls are 1mm thick, if you have a 0.4mm nozzle, Cura may give only 2 lines for every wall, so you get a wall consisting of 0.4mm plastic, 0.2mm air and then 0.4mm plastic again, which is really fragile. For me, I used a 0.3mm nozzle, Cura then uses multiple plastic lines to create a solid 1mm wall. Maybe this can also be a solution for you?
Yes, there is a big difference between the two STL's! First, I printed a fan duct using the official dimensions, when I observed that the fan duct did not fit but broke instead, I measured the real dimensions of my heatsink and saw a big difference of multiple millimeters.
Can you please share your final result? I am curious about the pictures :)
comments.author: jcmsys

These are just some basic riser legs to lift up a laptop that is in the corner of my office acting as a server. It doesn't get too hot so trying to keep it cool isn't really the goal here, mostly im trying to keep it off of a flat surface so that it doesn't get as hot is all. I will probably rework one of the legs to be able to put a fan in it in the future.

You will need to print 2 Lefts and 2 Rights, arrange them to the corners of the underside of the laptop and you should be set.  
Currently I have done mine on Medium quality with about 8% infill is more than sufficient for my needs.  
This is a work in process, with my printer I have not been able to bridge correctly to produce this part flawlessly regardless what direction its standing on the build table.. I have found laying on its side produced the most reasonable results for my taste.  
*Printing with a Wanhao Duplicator 4

title: Shapeoko Limit Switch Mount for HIGHLY ELECTRIC COMPANY SS0505A Switch

description.text:
Since I started playing with my 3D printer I loved how it homed itself and then started printing. Since my shapeoko needs to be manually homed and such, it hasn't seen much use, so I decided to add limit switches to it, and make cutting with it a much more automated process.  
Here you'll find + and - mounts for the X and Y axes, they are to be screwed onto the carriages. A drop of crazy glue should work perfectly to hold the switches in place, although with a tighter clearance, the switches could be kept in place with friction.

title: Stevenson screen for wireless meteorological sensor

description.text: A Stevenson screen is an outdoor shelter for your meteorological sensors, such as those that come along with your electronic home weather station. The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) agreed standard for the height of the screen is between 1.25 m (4ft 1 in) and 2 m (6ft 7 in). Its purpose is to provide a standardized environment in which to measure temperature, humidity, dew point and atmospheric pressure. The louvered design allows for the instrument to be sheltered from direct sunlight and rain, yet air is able to flow through the screen unrestricted.

Print out one top-part and one bottom-part, and then as many middle-parts as necessary. The parts are designed to snap together (inspired by tbuser's Pin Connectors), so no tools required for assembly. The Stevenson screen is designed to be placed on a pole; one wood-screw and a washer required. The pole in the pictures is a Kelleher 6 ft white vinyl coated closet pole acquired from a local home improvement store.   
IMPORTANT: Please print in WHITE color in accordance to the WMO agreed standard.

My propane regulator requires a 7/8" wrench to attach it to a propane tank.
Newer designs have a plastic thumbscrew that fits over the metal parts and allows you to screw the regulator to the propane tank by hand.
So, I created an adapter for my propane regulator to eliminate the need for a wrench to attach my regulator to the tank.
See instructions for what you need and how this may help you.

Measure your regulator and compare it to the files I have created.
My part is for a 20 year old burner, but I think that none of the dimensions have changed.
I'd advise you to print the parts with a high infill percentage because these regulators see a lot of abuse.
You will also need two machine screws and hex nuts to hold this assembly together.

description.text: A tribute to Edward Snowden's badassery in blowing the whistle (see what i did thar) on the NSA's autocrat-candy surveillance programs. This whistle doesn't actually make noise, but whistle noises aren't good for opsec, so it's a feature not a bug. You're welcome to change it though if you're a whistle expert. I've been able to print this without supports on NYC Resistor's Replicator 2. The little ball at the top should but cut off and squeezed into the opening in the chamber on top of the whistle. You can also use an airsoft BB, which you can easily find in most places except NYC because this city hates airsoft, cool park statues, and freedom.

description.text:
Okay, this one's just kind of crazy. It's loud, inefficient, and persnickety. You only get about 3 minutes of flight time from a 2200mAh 3S battery. So if that's your bag, this is an aircraft for you! It uses the top & bottom build plates (and modified cleanflight firmware) from Excelsior Bravo. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:825920) EDFs are EDF55 with H300 Motor from HobbyKing
ESCs are Afro 20A
Battery (as shown) is 2200mAh 3S. (May not be the best choice.)
Cross tube is ~124mm
Rear tube is ~200mm If you build one, God have mercy on you. :-P
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OetzGroOP3w Update- It seems to fly better with a 1600mAh 4S battery:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hd24_7lb88g

Use nylock nuts on the EDF mount rings, and don't tighten them down all the way.  (Doing so flexes the housing enough to make the impeller bind.)  I backed each one out until the impellers didn't scrape.

Just to see if I could print something highly interlinked in one go, I created a Ring Mail design in OpenSCAD for fun.  
[Now with Customizer support.]

This is a hard item to print. All the little parts will want to pop off of the board, due to low surface area. You may need to use a raft, or brim, or a print-bed surface preparation like a PVA glue wash to get the parts to stick tightly. If you need to tweak the sizes for this design:
  • Unpack the .zip file.
  • Edit the .scad file to tweak the parameters.
  • Open the .scad file with OpenSCAD.
  • Select Render from the Design menu.
  • Select "Export as STL..." from the File->Export menu.
  • Save the STL file.
  • Slice the STL file.
  • Print.

author: ignisuti

description.text: I saw someone else's printed Apple Watch stand, and figured I'd try to see how close I could get to replicating its curves and shape parametrically using my personal GDMUtils OpenSCAD library.

Print with supports turned on. If you need to tweak the sizes for this design:
  • Unpack the .zip file.
  • Edit the .scad file to tweak the parameters.
  • Open the .scad file with OpenSCAD.
  • Select Render from the Design menu.
  • Select "Export as STL..." from the File->Export menu.
  • Save the STL file.
  • Slice the STL file.
  • Print.
